title: Duncan Baillie
text:
<a href="Lieutenant-general%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Lieutenant-General</a> Duncan James Baillie (18 October 1826 — 27 July 1890) was a <a href="Scottish%20people">Scottish</a> first-class <a href="cricket">cricket</a>er and <a href="British%20Army">British Army</a> officer.
The son of the <a href="Scottish%20people">Scot</a> Colonel <a href="Hugh%20Duncan%20Baillie">Hugh Duncan Baillie</a> of <a href="Redcastle">Redcastle</a>, he was born at <a href="Marylebone">Marylebone</a> in October 1826 and was educated at <a href="Eton%20College">Eton College</a>. He was commissioned into the <a href="Royal%20Horse%20Guards">Royal Horse Guards</a> when he purchased the rank of <a href="Cornet%20%28rank%29">cornet</a> in February 1845, with Baillie later purchasing the rank of <a href="Lieutenant%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">lieutenant</a> in September 1847. He played <a href="first-class%20cricket">first-class cricket</a> for the <a href="Marylebone%20Cricket%20Club">Marylebone Cricket Club</a> (MCC) against <a href="Cambridge%20University%20Cricket%20Club">Cambridge University</a> at <a href="Fenner%27s">Fenner's</a> in 1850. Playing alongside his brother <a href="Alfred%20Baillie">Alfred</a> in the MCC side, he was dismissed in their first innings for 8 runs by <a href="David%20Buchanan%20%28cricketer%29">David Buchanan</a>, while in their second innings he was dismissed by the same bowler for 4 runs. In April 1854, he purchased the rank of <a href="Captain%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">captain</a>, later purchasing the rank of <a href="Major%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">major</a> in June 1866. In December of the same year he purchased the rank of <a href="Lieutenant%20colonel%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">lieutenant colonel</a>, with promotion to <a href="Colonel%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">colonel</a> under the provisions of the Royal Warrant following in June 1871. Baillie retired from active service in December 1875 and was placed on the <a href="half-pay">half-pay</a> list. He was made a <a href="Lieutenant-general%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">lieutenant-general</a> in March 1882. Baillie was a <a href="deputy%20lieutenant">deputy lieutenant</a> and <a href="Justice_of_the_peace%23Scotland">justice of the peace</a> for the <a href="County%20of%20Nairn">County of Nairnshire</a>. He died at <a href="Nairn">Nairn</a> in July 1890. Baillie was married to Anne Glentworth Burnaby in 1862, with whom he had eleven children. His eldest son Ronald Hugh Baillie became an <a href="advocate">advocate</a> in the Scottish courts and followed his father to become a justice of the peace and deputy lieutenant in Nairnshire.
